Variant.Description: Request addition of quality inspection criteria.
Variant.Justification: While the clause specifies the production according to AG-Guss-001, it lacks details on how quality will be ensured.
Variant.NegotiationArgument: To ensure the parts meet our standards, we need to include specific quality inspection criteria and the frequency of inspections.

Variant.Description: Propose inclusion of delivery timelines and penalties for delays.
Variant.Justification: The clause does not address the critical aspect of delivery timelines, which is essential for our production planning.
Variant.NegotiationArgument: We need to set clear delivery timelines and penalties for delays to ensure our production schedules are not disrupted.

Variant.Description: Insist on a comprehensive warranty and liability clause for defective parts.
Variant.Justification: The current clause does not protect our interests in case of defects or failures in the cast parts.
Variant.NegotiationArgument: To safeguard our interests, we need a comprehensive warranty and liability clause that covers defects and ensures quick replacement or compensation.

Clause.Text: Der Auftragnehmer sicht die Einhaltung der Spezifikation und übliche Gussqualität zu. Gewährleistungsfrist: 18 Monate ab Lieferung. Nacherfüllung nach Wahl des Auftragnehmers. Kosten trägt der Auftragnehmer, jedoch ohne Aus- und Einbaukosten. Rügefrist § 377 HGB: 5 Werktage für offene, 7 Werktage nach Entdeckung für versteckte Mängel. Qualität gemäß Datenblatt. Geringfügige Abweichungen sind zulässig. Gewährleistung: 24 Monate ab Lieferung. Nacherfüllung nach Wahl des Verkäufers. Käufer trägt Kosten für Aus- und Einbau. Rügefrist § 377 HGB: 3 Werktage für offene, 5 Werktage nach Entdeckung für versteckte Mängel.

Variant.Description: Extend the warranty period to 36 months and ensure the supplier covers all costs, including installation and removal costs.
Variant.Justification: This variant provides the longest warranty period and the most comprehensive cost coverage, ensuring minimal financial risk for the customer.
Variant.NegotiationArgument: A longer warranty period and comprehensive cost coverage will provide us with greater security and demonstrate your commitment to the quality of your products.

Variant.Description: Maintain the warranty period at 24 months, but negotiate for the supplier to cover installation and removal costs.
Variant.Justification: This variant balances the warranty period with additional cost coverage, providing a reasonable compromise between risk and benefit.
Variant.NegotiationArgument: Covering installation and removal costs will show your willingness to stand behind your products and provide us with added value without extending the warranty period.

Variant.Description: Accept the 24-month warranty period with the customer covering installation and removal costs, but negotiate for a more flexible notice period for defects.
Variant.Justification: This variant accepts the current warranty terms but seeks to improve the notice period for defects, providing some additional protection for the customer.
Variant.NegotiationArgument: A more flexible notice period for defects will allow us to better manage our quality control processes and demonstrate your understanding of our operational needs.

Variant.Description: Reduce the warranty period to 18 months and require the customer to cover all costs, including installation and removal costs.
Variant.Justification: This variant significantly reduces the warranty period and shifts all costs to the customer, representing a high level of risk and burden.
Variant.NegotiationArgument: A shorter warranty period and shifting all costs to us is not acceptable as it increases our risk and financial burden significantly. We need a more balanced agreement that reflects our long-term partnership goals.

Clause.Text: Liefertermine sind Planungstermine. Lieferung FCA Duisburg (Incoterms 2020). Verzugsschaden nur bei grober Fahrlässigkeit oder Vorsatz des Auftragnehmers. Lieferzeiten sind unverbindliche Schätzungen. Lieferung EXW Leipzig (Incoterms 2020). Keine Haftung für Lieferverzug, außer bei Vorsatz oder grober Fahrlässigkeit.

Variant.Description: Delivery dates are planning dates. Delivery FCA Duisburg (Incoterms 2020).
Variant.Justification: This clause is unacceptable because it imposes a strict delivery schedule on the customer without any flexibility. The delivery term FCA Duisburg also places the responsibility for the goods on the customer once they are loaded on the delivery vehicle, which is not favorable for the customer.
Variant.NegotiationArgument: We propose changing the delivery term to DDP (Delivered Duty Paid) to our designated location. This would ensure that the supplier takes full responsibility for the delivery, including customs clearance and all risks until the goods are delivered to our doorstep.

Variant.Description: Delay damage only in case of gross negligence or intent of the contractor.
Variant.Justification: This clause is acceptable as it provides some protection to the customer in case of significant delays caused by the contractor's gross negligence or intentional actions.
Variant.NegotiationArgument: We can accept this clause as it provides a reasonable level of protection for our interests. However, we would like to ensure that the definition of 'gross negligence' is clearly outlined in the contract to avoid any misunderstandings.

Variant.Description: Delivery times are non-binding estimates. Delivery EXW Leipzig (Incoterms 2020).
Variant.Justification: This clause is most favorable to the customer as it provides flexibility in delivery times and the delivery term EXW Leipzig places the minimum responsibility on the customer.
Variant.NegotiationArgument: We are satisfied with this clause as it allows us the flexibility to plan our operations without being strictly bound by delivery times. The EXW Leipzig term also ensures that we have control over the transport and insurance of the goods from the supplier's warehouse.

Variant.Description: No liability for delivery delay, except in case of intent or gross negligence.
Variant.Justification: This clause is balanced as it provides some protection to the customer in case of significant delays caused by the supplier's intentional actions or gross negligence, while also acknowledging that minor delays can occur.
Variant.NegotiationArgument: We can accept this clause with a slight modification. We propose adding a notification requirement where the supplier must inform us of any potential delays as soon as they become aware of them. This will allow us to adjust our plans accordingly and mitigate any potential impacts.

Clause.Text: Preise gemäß Angebot, Anpassung bei Rohstoffpreisänderung > 10% vorbehalten. Zahlung: 30 Tage netto.

Variant.Description: Fixed prices for the entire contract duration with no adjustments.
Variant.Justification: This variant provides the highest level of price predictability and budget stability for the customer.
Variant.NegotiationArgument: In today's volatile market, our organization needs stability. We are looking for long term partners who can provide fixed pricing. We are happy to negotiate other terms, but we need to fix pricing.

Variant.Description: Prices as quoted, with adjustments only if raw material prices change by more than 20%.
Variant.Justification: This variant offers a balance between price stability and flexibility for the supplier.
Variant.NegotiationArgument: We understand raw material prices can fluctuate. However, we need to have a balance between market conditions and our budget. We are willing to accept a 20% threshold to ensure both parties are protected.

Variant.Description: Prices as quoted, with adjustments if raw material prices change by more than 15%.
Variant.Justification: This variant is acceptable but provides less price stability for the customer compared to the most favorable or balanced variants.
Variant.NegotiationArgument: We are willing to meet you in the middle and accept a 15% threshold. However, we need to be clear on when this clause can be invoked and prices can change.

Variant.Description: Prices as quoted, with adjustments if raw material prices change by more than 10%.
Variant.Justification: This variant provides too much uncertainty for the customer's budget planning.
Variant.NegotiationArgument: This clause is too volatile for our budget planning. We need more stability in pricing. We are happy to discuss other terms, but this clause is not acceptable in its current form.

Clause.Text: Deutsches Recht (ohne UN-Kaufrecht). Gerichtsstand Leipzig. Salvatorische Klausel.

Variant.Description: German law (excluding UN Convention on Contracts for the International Sale of Goods).
Variant.Justification: The clause specifies German law but excludes the UN Convention on Contracts for the International Sale of Goods (CISG), which could provide additional protections for international sales. This is most favorable as it avoids potential complexities and uncertainties associated with the CISG.
Variant.NegotiationArgument: We prefer to keep the clause as is, specifying German law without the CISG, to ensure clarity and predictability in our contractual relationship.

Variant.Description: German law (including UN Convention on Contracts for the International Sale of Goods). Jurisdiction: Leipzig. Severability clause.
Variant.Justification: This variant includes the CISG, which can be beneficial for international sales contracts, but retains German law and the jurisdiction of Leipzig. The severability clause ensures that the rest of the contract remains valid if any part is found invalid.
Variant.NegotiationArgument: We propose including the CISG to benefit from its international sales provisions, while keeping German law and Leipzig as the jurisdiction. The severability clause adds an extra layer of contractual security.

Variant.Description: German law (including UN Convention on Contracts for the International Sale of Goods). Jurisdiction: Leipzig or the courts of the customer's place of business. Severability clause.
Variant.Justification: This variant is acceptable as it includes the CISG and provides flexibility in jurisdiction, allowing for Leipzig or the customer's place of business. This can be more convenient for the customer while still maintaining the severability clause.
Variant.NegotiationArgument: We suggest including the CISG and allowing for jurisdiction in either Leipzig or our place of business. This provides us with more flexibility and convenience in case of disputes, while the severability clause ensures contractual stability.

Variant.Description: German law (excluding UN Convention on Contracts for the International Sale of Goods). Jurisdiction: Seller's place of business. No severability clause.
Variant.Justification: This variant is unacceptable as it excludes the CISG, specifies the seller's place of business for jurisdiction, which could be inconvenient, and lacks a severability clause, potentially invalidating the entire contract if any part is found invalid.
Variant.NegotiationArgument: We cannot accept a clause that excludes the CISG, specifies the seller's place of business for jurisdiction, and lacks a severability clause. This puts us at a significant disadvantage in terms of legal protections and convenience.
